00014 /*
00015  NOTES:
00016 
00017  - The print* functions print to cerr. This allows our testing frameworks (like sass-spec) to ignore the output, which
00018    is very helpful when debugging. The format of the output is mainly to wrap things in square brackets to match what
00019    ruby already outputs (to make comparisons easier).
00020 
00021  - For the direct porting effort, we're trying to port method-for-method until we get all the tests passing.
00022    Where applicable, I've tried to include the ruby code above the function for reference until all our tests pass.
00023    The ruby code isn't always directly portable, so I've tried to include any modified ruby code that was actually
00024    used for the porting.
00025 
00026  - DO NOT try to optimize yet. We get a tremendous benefit out of comparing the output of each stage of the extend to the ruby
00027    output at the same stage. This makes it much easier to determine where problems are. Try to keep as close to
00028    the ruby code as you can until we have all the sass-spec tests passing. Then, we should optimize. However, if you see
00029    something that could probably be optimized, let's not forget it. Add a // TODO: or // IMPROVEMENT: comment.
00030 
00031  - Coding conventions in this file (these may need to be changed before merging back into master)
00032    - Very basic hungarian notation:
00033      p prefix for pointers (pSelector)
00034      no prefix for value types and references (selector)
00035    - Use STL iterators where possible
00036    - prefer verbose naming over terse naming
00037    - use typedefs for STL container types for make maintenance easier
00038 
00039  - You may see a lot of comments that say "// TODO: is this the correct combinator?". See the comment referring to combinators
00040    in extendCompoundSelector for a more extensive explanation of my confusion. I think our divergence in data model from ruby
00041    sass causes this to be necessary.
00042 
00043 
00044  GLOBAL TODOS:
00045 
00046  - wrap the contents of the print functions in DEBUG preprocesser conditionals so they will be optimized away in non-debug mode.
00047 
00048  - consider making the extend* functions member functions to avoid passing around ctx and subsetMap map around. This has the
00049    drawback that the implementation details of the operator are then exposed to the outside world, which is not ideal and
00050    can cause additional compile time dependencies.
00051 
00052  - mark the helper methods in this file static to given them compilation unit linkage.
00053 
00054  - implement parent directive matching
00055 
00056  - fix compilation warnings for unused Extend members if we really don't need those references anymore.
00057  */
00058

00070   // TODO: move the ast specific ostream operators into ast.hpp/ast.cpp
00071   ostream& operator<<(ostream& os, const Complex_Selector::Combinator combinator) {
00072     switch (combinator) {
00073       case Complex_Selector::ANCESTOR_OF: os << "\" \""; break;
00074       case Complex_Selector::PARENT_OF:   os << "\">\""; break;
00075       case Complex_Selector::PRECEDES:    os << "\"~\""; break;
00076       case Complex_Selector::ADJACENT_TO: os << "\"+\""; break;
00077     }
00078 
00079     return os;
00080   }

00110   ostream& operator<<(ostream& os, Complex_Selector& complexSelector) {
00111     To_String to_string;
00112 
00113     os << "[";
00114     Complex_Selector* pIter = &complexSelector;
00115     bool first = true;
00116     while (pIter) {
00117       if (pIter->combinator() != Complex_Selector::ANCESTOR_OF) {
00118         if (!first) {
00119           os << ", ";
00120         }
00121         first = false;
00122         os << pIter->combinator();
00123       }
00124 
00125       if (!first) {
00126         os << ", ";
00127       }
00128       first = false;
00129 
00130       if (pIter->head()) {
00131         os << pIter->head()->perform(&to_string);
00132       } else {
00133         os << "NULL_HEAD";
00134       }
00135 
00136       pIter = pIter->tail();
00137     }
00138     os << "]";
00139 
00140     return os;
00141   }

00164   // Print a string representation of a SourcesSet
00165   static void printSourcesSet(SourcesSet& sources, Context& ctx, const char* message=NULL, bool newline=true) {
00166     To_String to_string;
00167 
00168     if (message) {
00169       cerr << message;
00170     }
00171 
00172     // Convert to a deque of strings so we can sort since order doesn't matter in a set. This should cut down on
00173     // the differences we see when debug printing.
00174     typedef deque<string> SourceStrings;
00175     SourceStrings sourceStrings;
00176     for (SourcesSet::iterator iterator = sources.begin(), iteratorEnd = sources.end(); iterator != iteratorEnd; ++iterator) {
00177       Complex_Selector* pSource = *iterator;
00178       stringstream sstream;
00179       sstream << complexSelectorToNode(pSource, ctx);
00180       sourceStrings.push_back(sstream.str());
00181     }
00182 
00183     // Sort to get consistent output
00184     std::sort(sourceStrings.begin(), sourceStrings.end());
00185 
00186     cerr << "SourcesSet[";
00187     for (SourceStrings::iterator iterator = sourceStrings.begin(), iteratorEnd = sourceStrings.end(); iterator != iteratorEnd; ++iterator) {
00188       string source = *iterator;
00189       if (iterator != sourceStrings.begin()) {
00190         cerr << ", ";
00191       }
00192       cerr << source;
00193     }
00194     cerr << "]";
00195 
00196     if (newline) {
00197       cerr << endl;
00198     }
00199   }

00239   static bool parentSuperselector(Complex_Selector* pOne, Complex_Selector* pTwo, Context& ctx) {
00240     // TODO: figure out a better way to create a Complex_Selector from scratch
00241     // TODO: There's got to be a better way. This got ugly quick...
00242     Position noPosition(-1, -1, -1);
00243     Type_Selector fakeParent(ParserState("[FAKE]"), "temp");
00244     Compound_Selector fakeHead(ParserState("[FAKE]"), 1 /*size*/);
00245     fakeHead.elements().push_back(&fakeParent);
00246     Complex_Selector fakeParentContainer(ParserState("[FAKE]"), Complex_Selector::ANCESTOR_OF, &fakeHead /*head*/, NULL /*tail*/);
00247 
00248     pOne->set_innermost(&fakeParentContainer, Complex_Selector::ANCESTOR_OF);
00249     pTwo->set_innermost(&fakeParentContainer, Complex_Selector::ANCESTOR_OF);
00250 
00251     bool isSuperselector = pOne->is_superselector_of(pTwo);
00252 
00253     pOne->clear_innermost();
00254     pTwo->clear_innermost();
00255 
00256     return isSuperselector;
00257   }

00259   void nodeToComplexSelectorDeque(const Node& node, ComplexSelectorDeque& out, Context& ctx) {
00260     for (NodeDeque::iterator iter = node.collection()->begin(), iterEnd = node.collection()->end(); iter != iterEnd; iter++) {
00261       Node& child = *iter;
00262       out.push_back(nodeToComplexSelector(child, ctx));
00263     }
00264   }
00265 
00266   Node complexSelectorDequeToNode(const ComplexSelectorDeque& deque, Context& ctx) {
00267     Node result = Node::createCollection();
00268 
00269     for (ComplexSelectorDeque::const_iterator iter = deque.begin(), iterEnd = deque.end(); iter != iterEnd; iter++) {
00270       Complex_Selector* pChild = *iter;
00271       result.collection()->push_back(complexSelectorToNode(pChild, ctx));
00272     }
00273 
00274     return result;
00275   }

00277   class LcsCollectionComparator {
00278   public:
00279     LcsCollectionComparator(Context& ctx) : mCtx(ctx) {}
00280 
00281     Context& mCtx;
00282 
00283     bool operator()(Complex_Selector* pOne, Complex_Selector* pTwo, Complex_Selector*& pOut) const {
00284       /*
00285       This code is based on the following block from ruby sass' subweave
00286         do |s1, s2|
00287           next s1 if s1 == s2
00288           next unless s1.first.is_a?(SimpleSequence) && s2.first.is_a?(SimpleSequence)
00289           next s2 if parent_superselector?(s1, s2)
00290           next s1 if parent_superselector?(s2, s1)
00291         end
00292       */
00293 
00294       if (selectors_equal(*pOne, *pTwo, true /*simpleSelectorOrderDependent*/)) {
00295         pOut = pOne;
00296         return true;
00297       }
00298 
00299       if (pOne->combinator() != Complex_Selector::ANCESTOR_OF || pTwo->combinator() != Complex_Selector::ANCESTOR_OF) {
00300         return false;
00301       }
00302 
00303       if (parentSuperselector(pOne, pTwo, mCtx)) {
00304         pOut = pTwo;
00305         return true;
00306       }
00307 
00308       if (parentSuperselector(pTwo, pOne, mCtx)) {
00309         pOut = pOne;
00310         return true;
00311       }
00312 
00313       return false;
00314     }
00315   };

00318   /*
00319   This is the equivalent of ruby's Sass::Util.lcs_backtrace.
00320 
00321   # Computes a single longest common subsequence for arrays x and y.
00322   # Algorithm from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longest_common_subsequence_problem#Reading_out_an_LCS
00323   */
00324   void lcs_backtrace(const LCSTable& c, ComplexSelectorDeque& x, ComplexSelectorDeque& y, int i, int j, const LcsCollectionComparator& comparator, ComplexSelectorDeque& out) {
00325     //DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "LCSBACK: X=" << x << " Y=" << y << " I=" << i << " J=" << j)
00326     // TODO: make printComplexSelectorDeque and use DEBUG_EXEC AND DEBUG_PRINTLN HERE to get equivalent output
00327 
00328     if (i == 0 || j == 0) {
00329       DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "RETURNING EMPTY")
00330       return;
00331     }
00332 
00333 
00334     Complex_Selector* pCompareOut = NULL;
00335     if (comparator(x[i], y[j], pCompareOut)) {
00336       DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "RETURNING AFTER ELEM COMPARE")
00337       lcs_backtrace(c, x, y, i - 1, j - 1, comparator, out);
00338       out.push_back(pCompareOut);
00339       return;
00340     }
00341 
00342     if (c[i][j - 1] > c[i - 1][j]) {
00343       DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "RETURNING AFTER TABLE COMPARE")
00344       lcs_backtrace(c, x, y, i, j - 1, comparator, out);
00345       return;
00346     }
00347 
00348     DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "FINAL RETURN")
00349     lcs_backtrace(c, x, y, i - 1, j, comparator, out);
00350     return;
00351   }
00352 
00353   /*
00354   This is the equivalent of ruby's Sass::Util.lcs_table.
00355 
00356   # Calculates the memoization table for the Least Common Subsequence algorithm.
00357   # Algorithm from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longest_common_subsequence_problem#Computing_the_length_of_the_LCS
00358   */
00359   void lcs_table(const ComplexSelectorDeque& x, const ComplexSelectorDeque& y, const LcsCollectionComparator& comparator, LCSTable& out) {
00360     //DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "LCSTABLE: X=" << x << " Y=" << y)
00361     // TODO: make printComplexSelectorDeque and use DEBUG_EXEC AND DEBUG_PRINTLN HERE to get equivalent output
00362 
00363     LCSTable c(x.size(), vector<int>(y.size()));
00364 
00365     // These shouldn't be necessary since the vector will be initialized to 0 already.
00366     // x.size.times {|i| c[i][0] = 0}
00367     // y.size.times {|j| c[0][j] = 0}
00368 
00369     for (size_t i = 1; i < x.size(); i++) {
00370       for (size_t j = 1; j < y.size(); j++) {
00371         Complex_Selector* pCompareOut = NULL;
00372 
00373         if (comparator(x[i], y[j], pCompareOut)) {
00374           c[i][j] = c[i - 1][j - 1] + 1;
00375         } else {
00376           c[i][j] = max(c[i][j - 1], c[i - 1][j]);
00377         }
00378       }
00379     }
00380 
00381     out = c;
00382   }
00383 
00384   /*
00385   This is the equivalent of ruby's Sass::Util.lcs.
00386 
00387   # Computes a single longest common subsequence for `x` and `y`.
00388   # If there are more than one longest common subsequences,
00389   # the one returned is that which starts first in `x`.
00390 
00391   # @param x [NodeCollection]
00392   # @param y [NodeCollection]
00393   # @comparator An equality check between elements of `x` and `y`.
00394   # @return [NodeCollection] The LCS
00395 
00396   http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longest_common_subsequence_problem
00397   */
00398   void lcs(ComplexSelectorDeque& x, ComplexSelectorDeque& y, const LcsCollectionComparator& comparator, Context& ctx, ComplexSelectorDeque& out) {
00399     //DEBUG_PRINTLN(LCS, "LCS: X=" << x << " Y=" << y)
00400     // TODO: make printComplexSelectorDeque and use DEBUG_EXEC AND DEBUG_PRINTLN HERE to get equivalent output
00401 
00402     x.push_front(NULL);
00403     y.push_front(NULL);
00404 
00405     LCSTable table;
00406     lcs_table(x, y, comparator, table);
00407 
00408     return lcs_backtrace(table, x, y, static_cast<int>(x.size()) - 1, static_cast<int>(y.size()) - 1, comparator, out);
00409   }

00412   /*
00413    This is the equivalent of ruby's Sequence.trim.
00414 
00415    The following is the modified version of the ruby code that was more portable to C++. You
00416    should be able to drop it into ruby 3.2.19 and get the same results from ruby sass.
00417 
00418         # Avoid truly horrific quadratic behavior. TODO: I think there
00419         # may be a way to get perfect trimming without going quadratic.
00420         return seqses if seqses.size > 100
00421 
00422         # Keep the results in a separate array so we can be sure we aren't
00423         # comparing against an already-trimmed selector. This ensures that two
00424         # identical selectors don't mutually trim one another.
00425         result = seqses.dup
00426 
00427         # This is n^2 on the sequences, but only comparing between
00428         # separate sequences should limit the quadratic behavior.
00429         seqses.each_with_index do |seqs1, i|
00430           tempResult = []
00431 
00432           for seq1 in seqs1 do
00433             max_spec = 0
00434             for seq in _sources(seq1) do
00435               max_spec = [max_spec, seq.specificity].max
00436             end
00437 
00438 
00439             isMoreSpecificOuter = false
00440             for seqs2 in result do
00441               if seqs1.equal?(seqs2) then
00442                 next
00443               end
00444 
00445               # Second Law of Extend: the specificity of a generated selector
00446               # should never be less than the specificity of the extending
00447               # selector.
00448               #
00449               # See https://github.com/nex3/sass/issues/324.
00450               isMoreSpecificInner = false
00451               for seq2 in seqs2 do
00452                 isMoreSpecificInner = _specificity(seq2) >= max_spec && _superselector?(seq2, seq1)
00453                 if isMoreSpecificInner then
00454                   break
00455                 end
00456               end
00457 
00458               if isMoreSpecificInner then
00459                 isMoreSpecificOuter = true
00460                 break
00461               end
00462             end
00463 
00464             if !isMoreSpecificOuter then
00465               tempResult.push(seq1)
00466             end
00467           end
00468 
00469           result[i] = tempResult
00470 
00471         end
00472 
00473         result
00474    */
00475   /*
00476    - IMPROVEMENT: We could probably work directly in the output trimmed deque.
00477    */
00478   static Node trim(Node& seqses, Context& ctx) {
00479     // See the comments in the above ruby code before embarking on understanding this function.
00480 
00481     // Avoid poor performance in extreme cases.
00482     if (seqses.collection()->size() > 100) {
00483       return seqses;
00484     }
00485 
00486 
00487     DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "TRIM: " << seqses)
00488 
00489 
00490     Node result = Node::createCollection();
00491     result.plus(seqses);
00492 
00493     DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "RESULT INITIAL: " << result)
00494 
00495     // Normally we use the standard STL iterators, but in this case, we need to access the result collection by index since we're
00496     // iterating the input collection, computing a value, and then setting the result in the output collection. We have to keep track
00497     // of the index manually.
00498     int toTrimIndex = 0;
00499 
00500     for (NodeDeque::iterator seqsesIter = seqses.collection()->begin(), seqsesIterEnd = seqses.collection()->end(); seqsesIter != seqsesIterEnd; ++seqsesIter) {
00501       Node& seqs1 = *seqsesIter;
00502 
00503       DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "SEQS1: " << seqs1 << " " << toTrimIndex)
00504 
00505       Node tempResult = Node::createCollection();
00506 
00507       for (NodeDeque::iterator seqs1Iter = seqs1.collection()->begin(), seqs1EndIter = seqs1.collection()->end(); seqs1Iter != seqs1EndIter; ++seqs1Iter) {
00508         Node& seq1 = *seqs1Iter;
00509 
00510         Complex_Selector* pSeq1 = nodeToComplexSelector(seq1, ctx);
00511 
00512         // Compute the maximum specificity. This requires looking at the "sources" of the sequence. See SimpleSequence.sources in the ruby code
00513         // for a good description of sources.
00514         //
00515         // TODO: I'm pretty sure there's a bug in the sources code. It was implemented for sass-spec's 182_test_nested_extend_loop test.
00516         // While the test passes, I compared the state of each trim call to verify correctness. The last trim call had incorrect sources. We
00517         // had an extra source that the ruby version did not have. Without a failing test case, this is going to be extra hard to find. My
00518         // best guess at this point is that we're cloning an object somewhere and maintaining the sources when we shouldn't be. This is purely
00519         // a guess though.
00520         unsigned long maxSpecificity = 0;
00521         SourcesSet sources = pSeq1->sources();
00522 
00523         DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "TRIMASDF SEQ1: " << seq1)
00524         DEBUG_EXEC(TRIM, printSourcesSet(sources, ctx, "TRIMASDF SOURCES: "))
00525 
00526         for (SourcesSet::iterator sourcesSetIterator = sources.begin(), sourcesSetIteratorEnd = sources.end(); sourcesSetIterator != sourcesSetIteratorEnd; ++sourcesSetIterator) {
00527           const Complex_Selector* const pCurrentSelector = *sourcesSetIterator;
00528           maxSpecificity = max(maxSpecificity, pCurrentSelector->specificity());
00529         }
00530 
00531         DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "MAX SPECIFICITY: " << maxSpecificity)
00532 
00533         bool isMoreSpecificOuter = false;
00534 
00535         int resultIndex = 0;
00536 
00537         for (NodeDeque::iterator resultIter = result.collection()->begin(), resultIterEnd = result.collection()->end(); resultIter != resultIterEnd; ++resultIter) {
00538           Node& seqs2 = *resultIter;
00539 
00540           DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "SEQS1: " << seqs1)
00541           DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "SEQS2: " << seqs2)
00542 
00543           // Do not compare the same sequence to itself. The ruby call we're trying to
00544           // emulate is: seqs1.equal?(seqs2). equal? is an object comparison, not an equivalency comparision.
00545           // Since we have the same pointers in seqes and results, we can do a pointer comparision. seqs1 is
00546           // derived from seqses and seqs2 is derived from result.
00547           if (seqs1.collection() == seqs2.collection()) {
00548             DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "CONTINUE")
00549             continue;
00550           }
00551 
00552           bool isMoreSpecificInner = false;
00553 
00554           for (NodeDeque::iterator seqs2Iter = seqs2.collection()->begin(), seqs2IterEnd = seqs2.collection()->end(); seqs2Iter != seqs2IterEnd; ++seqs2Iter) {
00555             Node& seq2 = *seqs2Iter;
00556 
00557             Complex_Selector* pSeq2 = nodeToComplexSelector(seq2, ctx);
00558 
00559             DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "SEQ2 SPEC: " << pSeq2->specificity())
00560             DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "IS SPEC: " << pSeq2->specificity() << " >= " << maxSpecificity << " " << (pSeq2->specificity() >= maxSpecificity ? "true" : "false"))
00561             DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "IS SUPER: " << (pSeq2->is_superselector_of(pSeq1) ? "true" : "false"))
00562 
00563             isMoreSpecificInner = pSeq2->specificity() >= maxSpecificity && pSeq2->is_superselector_of(pSeq1);
00564 
00565             if (isMoreSpecificInner) {
00566               DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "FOUND MORE SPECIFIC")
00567               break;
00568             }
00569           }
00570 
00571           // If we found something more specific, we're done. Let the outer loop know and stop iterating.
00572           if (isMoreSpecificInner) {
00573             isMoreSpecificOuter = true;
00574             break;
00575           }
00576 
00577           resultIndex++;
00578         }
00579 
00580         if (!isMoreSpecificOuter) {
00581           DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "PUSHING: " << seq1)
00582           tempResult.collection()->push_back(seq1);
00583         }
00584 
00585       }
00586 
00587       DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "RESULT BEFORE ASSIGN: " << result)
00588       DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "TEMP RESULT: " << toTrimIndex << " " << tempResult)
00589       (*result.collection())[toTrimIndex] = tempResult;
00590 
00591       toTrimIndex++;
00592 
00593       DEBUG_PRINTLN(TRIM, "RESULT: " << result)
00594     }
00595 
00596     return result;
00597   }

00601   static bool parentSuperselector(const Node& one, const Node& two, Context& ctx) {
00602     // TODO: figure out a better way to create a Complex_Selector from scratch
00603     // TODO: There's got to be a better way. This got ugly quick...
00604     Position noPosition(-1, -1, -1);
00605     Type_Selector fakeParent(ParserState("[FAKE]"), "temp");
00606     Compound_Selector fakeHead(ParserState("[FAKE]"), 1 /*size*/);
00607     fakeHead.elements().push_back(&fakeParent);
00608     Complex_Selector fakeParentContainer(ParserState("[FAKE]"), Complex_Selector::ANCESTOR_OF, &fakeHead /*head*/, NULL /*tail*/);
00609 
00610     Complex_Selector* pOneWithFakeParent = nodeToComplexSelector(one, ctx);
00611     pOneWithFakeParent->set_innermost(&fakeParentContainer, Complex_Selector::ANCESTOR_OF);
00612     Complex_Selector* pTwoWithFakeParent = nodeToComplexSelector(two, ctx);
00613     pTwoWithFakeParent->set_innermost(&fakeParentContainer, Complex_Selector::ANCESTOR_OF);
00614 
00615     return pOneWithFakeParent->is_superselector_of(pTwoWithFakeParent);
00616   }
00617 
00618 
00619   class ParentSuperselectorChunker {
00620   public:
00621     ParentSuperselectorChunker(Node& lcs, Context& ctx) : mLcs(lcs), mCtx(ctx) {}
00622     Node& mLcs;
00623     Context& mCtx;
00624 
00625     bool operator()(const Node& seq) const {
00626       // {|s| parent_superselector?(s.first, lcs.first)}
00627       return parentSuperselector(seq.collection()->front(), mLcs.collection()->front(), mCtx);
00628     }
00629   };
00630 
00631   class SubweaveEmptyChunker {
00632   public:
00633     bool operator()(const Node& seq) const {
00634       // {|s| s.empty?}
00635 
00636       return seq.collection()->empty();
00637     }
00638   };
00639 
00640   /*
00641   # Takes initial subsequences of `seq1` and `seq2` and returns all
00642   # orderings of those subsequences. The initial subsequences are determined
00643   # by a block.
00644   #
00645   # Destructively removes the initial subsequences of `seq1` and `seq2`.
00646   #
00647   # For example, given `(A B C | D E)` and `(1 2 | 3 4 5)` (with `|`
00648   # denoting the boundary of the initial subsequence), this would return
00649   # `[(A B C 1 2), (1 2 A B C)]`. The sequences would then be `(D E)` and
00650   # `(3 4 5)`.
00651   #
00652   # @param seq1 [Array]
00653   # @param seq2 [Array]
00654   # @yield [a] Used to determine when to cut off the initial subsequences.
00655   #   Called repeatedly for each sequence until it returns true.
00656   # @yieldparam a [Array] A final subsequence of one input sequence after
00657   #   cutting off some initial subsequence.
00658   # @yieldreturn [Boolean] Whether or not to cut off the initial subsequence
00659   #   here.
00660   # @return [Array<Array>] All possible orderings of the initial subsequences.
00661   def chunks(seq1, seq2)
00662     chunk1 = []
00663     chunk1 << seq1.shift until yield seq1
00664     chunk2 = []
00665     chunk2 << seq2.shift until yield seq2
00666     return [] if chunk1.empty? && chunk2.empty?
00667     return [chunk2] if chunk1.empty?
00668     return [chunk1] if chunk2.empty?
00669     [chunk1 + chunk2, chunk2 + chunk1]
00670   end
00671   */
00672   template<typename ChunkerType>
00673   static Node chunks(Node& seq1, Node& seq2, const ChunkerType& chunker) {
00674     Node chunk1 = Node::createCollection();
00675     while (!chunker(seq1)) {
00676       chunk1.collection()->push_back(seq1.collection()->front());
00677       seq1.collection()->pop_front();
00678     }
00679 
00680     Node chunk2 = Node::createCollection();
00681     while (!chunker(seq2)) {
00682       chunk2.collection()->push_back(seq2.collection()->front());
00683       seq2.collection()->pop_front();
00684     }
00685 
00686     if (chunk1.collection()->empty() && chunk2.collection()->empty()) {
00687       DEBUG_PRINTLN(CHUNKS, "RETURNING BOTH EMPTY")
00688       return Node::createCollection();
00689     }
00690 
00691     if (chunk1.collection()->empty()) {
00692       Node chunk2Wrapper = Node::createCollection();
00693       chunk2Wrapper.collection()->push_back(chunk2);
00694       DEBUG_PRINTLN(CHUNKS, "RETURNING ONE EMPTY")
00695       return chunk2Wrapper;
00696     }
00697 
00698     if (chunk2.collection()->empty()) {
00699       Node chunk1Wrapper = Node::createCollection();
00700       chunk1Wrapper.collection()->push_back(chunk1);
00701       DEBUG_PRINTLN(CHUNKS, "RETURNING TWO EMPTY")
00702       return chunk1Wrapper;
00703     }
00704 
00705     Node perms = Node::createCollection();
00706 
00707     Node firstPermutation = Node::createCollection();
00708     firstPermutation.collection()->insert(firstPermutation.collection()->end(), chunk1.collection()->begin(), chunk1.collection()->end());
00709     firstPermutation.collection()->insert(firstPermutation.collection()->end(), chunk2.collection()->begin(), chunk2.collection()->end());
00710     perms.collection()->push_back(firstPermutation);
00711 
00712     Node secondPermutation = Node::createCollection();
00713     secondPermutation.collection()->insert(secondPermutation.collection()->end(), chunk2.collection()->begin(), chunk2.collection()->end());
00714     secondPermutation.collection()->insert(secondPermutation.collection()->end(), chunk1.collection()->begin(), chunk1.collection()->end());
00715     perms.collection()->push_back(secondPermutation);
00716 
00717     DEBUG_PRINTLN(CHUNKS, "RETURNING PERM")
00718 
00719     return perms;
00720   }
00721 
00722 
00723   static Node groupSelectors(Node& seq, Context& ctx) {
00724     Node newSeq = Node::createCollection();
00725 
00726     Node tail = Node::createCollection();
00727     tail.plus(seq);
00728 
00729     while (!tail.collection()->empty()) {
00730       Node head = Node::createCollection();
00731 
00732       do {
00733         head.collection()->push_back(tail.collection()->front());
00734         tail.collection()->pop_front();
00735       } while (!tail.collection()->empty() && (head.collection()->back().isCombinator() || tail.collection()->front().isCombinator()));
00736 
00737       newSeq.collection()->push_back(head);
00738     }
00739 
00740     return newSeq;
00741   }
00742 
00743 
00744   static void getAndRemoveInitialOps(Node& seq, Node& ops) {
00745     NodeDeque& seqCollection = *(seq.collection());
00746     NodeDeque& opsCollection = *(ops.collection());
00747 
00748     while (seqCollection.size() > 0 && seqCollection.front().isCombinator()) {
00749       opsCollection.push_back(seqCollection.front());
00750       seqCollection.pop_front();
00751     }
00752   }
00753 
00754 
00755   static void getAndRemoveFinalOps(Node& seq, Node& ops) {
00756     NodeDeque& seqCollection = *(seq.collection());
00757     NodeDeque& opsCollection = *(ops.collection());
00758 
00759     while (seqCollection.size() > 0 && seqCollection.back().isCombinator()) {
00760       opsCollection.push_back(seqCollection.back()); // Purposefully reversed to match ruby code
00761       seqCollection.pop_back();
00762     }
00763   }
00764 
00765 
00766   /*
00767       def merge_initial_ops(seq1, seq2)
00768         ops1, ops2 = [], []
00769         ops1 << seq1.shift while seq1.first.is_a?(String)
00770         ops2 << seq2.shift while seq2.first.is_a?(String)
00771 
00772         newline = false
00773         newline ||= !!ops1.shift if ops1.first == "\n"
00774         newline ||= !!ops2.shift if ops2.first == "\n"
00775 
00776         # If neither sequence is a subsequence of the other, they cannot be
00777         # merged successfully
00778         lcs = Sass::Util.lcs(ops1, ops2)
00779         return unless lcs == ops1 || lcs == ops2
00780         return (newline ? ["\n"] : []) + (ops1.size > ops2.size ? ops1 : ops2)
00781       end
00782   */
00783   static Node mergeInitialOps(Node& seq1, Node& seq2, Context& ctx) {
00784     Node ops1 = Node::createCollection();
00785     Node ops2 = Node::createCollection();
00786 
00787     getAndRemoveInitialOps(seq1, ops1);
00788     getAndRemoveInitialOps(seq2, ops2);
00789 
00790     // TODO: Do we have this information available to us?
00791     // newline = false
00792     // newline ||= !!ops1.shift if ops1.first == "\n"
00793     // newline ||= !!ops2.shift if ops2.first == "\n"
00794 
00795     // If neither sequence is a subsequence of the other, they cannot be merged successfully
00796     DefaultLcsComparator lcsDefaultComparator;
00797     Node opsLcs = lcs(ops1, ops2, lcsDefaultComparator, ctx);
00798 
00799     if (!(opsLcs == ops1 || opsLcs == ops2)) {
00800       return Node::createNil();
00801     }
00802 
00803     // TODO: more newline logic
00804     // return (newline ? ["\n"] : []) + (ops1.size > ops2.size ? ops1 : ops2)
00805 
00806     return (ops1.collection()->size() > ops2.collection()->size() ? ops1 : ops2);
00807   }
00808 
00809 
00810   /*
00811       def merge_final_ops(seq1, seq2, res = [])
00812 
00813 
00814         # This code looks complicated, but it's actually just a bunch of special
00815         # cases for interactions between different combinators.
00816         op1, op2 = ops1.first, ops2.first
00817         if op1 && op2
00818           sel1 = seq1.pop
00819           sel2 = seq2.pop
00820           if op1 == '~' && op2 == '~'
00821             if sel1.superselector?(sel2)
00822               res.unshift sel2, '~'
00823             elsif sel2.superselector?(sel1)
00824               res.unshift sel1, '~'
00825             else
00826               merged = sel1.unify(sel2.members, sel2.subject?)
00827               res.unshift [
00828                 [sel1, '~', sel2, '~'],
00829                 [sel2, '~', sel1, '~'],
00830                 ([merged, '~'] if merged)
00831               ].compact
00832             end
00833           elsif (op1 == '~' && op2 == '+') || (op1 == '+' && op2 == '~')
00834             if op1 == '~'
00835               tilde_sel, plus_sel = sel1, sel2
00836             else
00837               tilde_sel, plus_sel = sel2, sel1
00838             end
00839 
00840             if tilde_sel.superselector?(plus_sel)
00841               res.unshift plus_sel, '+'
00842             else
00843               merged = plus_sel.unify(tilde_sel.members, tilde_sel.subject?)
00844               res.unshift [
00845                 [tilde_sel, '~', plus_sel, '+'],
00846                 ([merged, '+'] if merged)
00847               ].compact
00848             end
00849           elsif op1 == '>' && %w[~ +].include?(op2)
00850             res.unshift sel2, op2
00851             seq1.push sel1, op1
00852           elsif op2 == '>' && %w[~ +].include?(op1)
00853             res.unshift sel1, op1
00854             seq2.push sel2, op2
00855           elsif op1 == op2
00856             return unless merged = sel1.unify(sel2.members, sel2.subject?)
00857             res.unshift merged, op1
00858           else
00859             # Unknown selector combinators can't be unified
00860             return
00861           end
00862           return merge_final_ops(seq1, seq2, res)
00863         elsif op1
00864           seq2.pop if op1 == '>' && seq2.last && seq2.last.superselector?(seq1.last)
00865           res.unshift seq1.pop, op1
00866           return merge_final_ops(seq1, seq2, res)
00867         else # op2
00868           seq1.pop if op2 == '>' && seq1.last && seq1.last.superselector?(seq2.last)
00869           res.unshift seq2.pop, op2
00870           return merge_final_ops(seq1, seq2, res)
00871         end
00872       end
00873   */
00874   static Node mergeFinalOps(Node& seq1, Node& seq2, Context& ctx, Node& res) {
00875 
00876     Node ops1 = Node::createCollection();
00877     Node ops2 = Node::createCollection();
00878 
00879     getAndRemoveFinalOps(seq1, ops1);
00880     getAndRemoveFinalOps(seq2, ops2);
00881 
00882     // TODO: do we have newlines to remove?
00883     // ops1.reject! {|o| o == "\n"}
00884     // ops2.reject! {|o| o == "\n"}
00885 
00886     if (ops1.collection()->empty() && ops2.collection()->empty()) {
00887       return res;
00888     }
00889 
00890     if (ops1.collection()->size() > 1 || ops2.collection()->size() > 1) {
00891       DefaultLcsComparator lcsDefaultComparator;
00892       Node opsLcs = lcs(ops1, ops2, lcsDefaultComparator, ctx);
00893 
00894       // If there are multiple operators, something hacky's going on. If one is a supersequence of the other, use that, otherwise give up.
00895 
00896       if (!(opsLcs == ops1 || opsLcs == ops2)) {
00897         return Node::createNil();
00898       }
00899 
00900       if (ops1.collection()->size() > ops2.collection()->size()) {
00901         res.collection()->insert(res.collection()->begin(), ops1.collection()->rbegin(), ops1.collection()->rend());
00902       } else {
00903         res.collection()->insert(res.collection()->begin(), ops2.collection()->rbegin(), ops2.collection()->rend());
00904       }
00905 
00906       return res;
00907     }
00908 
00909     if (!ops1.collection()->empty() && !ops2.collection()->empty()) {
00910 
00911       Node op1 = ops1.collection()->front();
00912       Node op2 = ops2.collection()->front();
00913 
00914       Node sel1 = seq1.collection()->back();
00915       seq1.collection()->pop_back();
00916 
00917       Node sel2 = seq2.collection()->back();
00918       seq2.collection()->pop_back();
00919 
00920       if (op1.combinator() == Complex_Selector::PRECEDES && op2.combinator() == Complex_Selector::PRECEDES) {
00921 
00922         if (sel1.selector()->is_superselector_of(sel2.selector())) {
00923 
00924           res.collection()->push_front(op1 /*PRECEDES - could have been op2 as well*/);
00925           res.collection()->push_front(sel2);
00926 
00927         } else if (sel2.selector()->is_superselector_of(sel1.selector())) {
00928 
00929           res.collection()->push_front(op1 /*PRECEDES - could have been op2 as well*/);
00930           res.collection()->push_front(sel1);
00931 
00932         } else {
00933 
00934           DEBUG_PRINTLN(ALL, "sel1: " << sel1)
00935           DEBUG_PRINTLN(ALL, "sel2: " << sel2)
00936 
00937           Complex_Selector* pMergedWrapper = sel1.selector()->clone(ctx); // Clone the Complex_Selector to get back to something we can transform to a node once we replace the head with the unification result
00938           // TODO: does subject matter? Ruby: return unless merged = sel1.unify(sel2.members, sel2.subject?)
00939           Compound_Selector* pMerged = sel1.selector()->head()->unify_with(sel2.selector()->head(), ctx);
00940           pMergedWrapper->head(pMerged);
00941 
00942           DEBUG_EXEC(ALL, printCompoundSelector(pMerged, "MERGED: "))
00943 
00944           Node newRes = Node::createCollection();
00945 
00946           Node firstPerm = Node::createCollection();
00947           firstPerm.collection()->push_back(sel1);
00948           firstPerm.collection()->push_back(Node::createCombinator(Complex_Selector::PRECEDES));
00949           firstPerm.collection()->push_back(sel2);
00950           firstPerm.collection()->push_back(Node::createCombinator(Complex_Selector::PRECEDES));
00951           newRes.collection()->push_back(firstPerm);
00952 
00953           Node secondPerm = Node::createCollection();
00954           secondPerm.collection()->push_back(sel2);
00955           secondPerm.collection()->push_back(Node::createCombinator(Complex_Selector::PRECEDES));
00956           secondPerm.collection()->push_back(sel1);
00957           secondPerm.collection()->push_back(Node::createCombinator(Complex_Selector::PRECEDES));
00958           newRes.collection()->push_back(secondPerm);
00959 
00960           if (pMerged) {
00961             Node mergedPerm = Node::createCollection();
00962             mergedPerm.collection()->push_back(Node::createSelector(pMergedWrapper, ctx));
00963             mergedPerm.collection()->push_back(Node::createCombinator(Complex_Selector::PRECEDES));
00964             newRes.collection()->push_back(mergedPerm);
00965           }
00966 
00967           res.collection()->push_front(newRes);
00968 
00969           DEBUG_PRINTLN(ALL, "RESULT: " << res)
00970 
00971         }
00972 
00973       } else if (((op1.combinator() == Complex_Selector::PRECEDES && op2.combinator() == Complex_Selector::ADJACENT_TO)) || ((op1.combinator() == Complex_Selector::ADJACENT_TO && op2.combinator() == Complex_Selector::PRECEDES))) {
00974 
00975           Node tildeSel = sel1;
00976           Node tildeOp = op1;
00977           Node plusSel = sel2;
00978           Node plusOp = op2;
00979           if (op1.combinator() != Complex_Selector::PRECEDES) {
00980             tildeSel = sel2;
00981             tildeOp = op2;
00982             plusSel = sel1;
00983             plusOp = op1;
00984           }
00985 
00986           if (tildeSel.selector()->is_superselector_of(plusSel.selector())) {
00987 
00988             res.collection()->push_front(plusOp);
00989             res.collection()->push_front(plusSel);
00990 
00991           } else {
00992 
00993             DEBUG_PRINTLN(ALL, "PLUS SEL: " << plusSel)
00994             DEBUG_PRINTLN(ALL, "TILDE SEL: " << tildeSel)
00995 
00996             Complex_Selector* pMergedWrapper = plusSel.selector()->clone(ctx); // Clone the Complex_Selector to get back to something we can transform to a node once we replace the head with the unification result
00997             // TODO: does subject matter? Ruby: merged = plus_sel.unify(tilde_sel.members, tilde_sel.subject?)
00998             Compound_Selector* pMerged = plusSel.selector()->head()->unify_with(tildeSel.selector()->head(), ctx);
00999             pMergedWrapper->head(pMerged);
01000 
01001             DEBUG_EXEC(ALL, printCompoundSelector(pMerged, "MERGED: "))
01002 
01003             Node newRes = Node::createCollection();
01004 
01005             Node firstPerm = Node::createCollection();
01006             firstPerm.collection()->push_back(tildeSel);
01007             firstPerm.collection()->push_back(Node::createCombinator(Complex_Selector::PRECEDES));
01008             firstPerm.collection()->push_back(plusSel);
01009             firstPerm.collection()->push_back(Node::createCombinator(Complex_Selector::ADJACENT_TO));
01010             newRes.collection()->push_back(firstPerm);
01011 
01012             if (pMerged) {
01013               Node mergedPerm = Node::createCollection();
01014               mergedPerm.collection()->push_back(Node::createSelector(pMergedWrapper, ctx));
01015               mergedPerm.collection()->push_back(Node::createCombinator(Complex_Selector::ADJACENT_TO));
01016               newRes.collection()->push_back(mergedPerm);
01017             }
01018 
01019             res.collection()->push_front(newRes);
01020 
01021             DEBUG_PRINTLN(ALL, "RESULT: " << res)
01022 
01023           }
01024       } else if (op1.combinator() == Complex_Selector::PARENT_OF && (op2.combinator() == Complex_Selector::PRECEDES || op2.combinator() == Complex_Selector::ADJACENT_TO)) {
01025 
01026         res.collection()->push_front(op2);
01027         res.collection()->push_front(sel2);
01028 
01029         seq2.collection()->push_back(sel1);
01030         seq2.collection()->push_back(op1);
01031 
01032       } else if (op2.combinator() == Complex_Selector::PARENT_OF && (op1.combinator() == Complex_Selector::PRECEDES || op1.combinator() == Complex_Selector::ADJACENT_TO)) {
01033 
01034         res.collection()->push_front(op1);
01035         res.collection()->push_front(sel1);
01036 
01037         seq2.collection()->push_back(sel2);
01038         seq2.collection()->push_back(op2);
01039 
01040       } else if (op1.combinator() == op2.combinator()) {
01041 
01042         DEBUG_PRINTLN(ALL, "sel1: " << sel1)
01043         DEBUG_PRINTLN(ALL, "sel2: " << sel2)
01044 
01045         Complex_Selector* pMergedWrapper = sel1.selector()->clone(ctx); // Clone the Complex_Selector to get back to something we can transform to a node once we replace the head with the unification result
01046         // TODO: does subject matter? Ruby: return unless merged = sel1.unify(sel2.members, sel2.subject?)
01047         Compound_Selector* pMerged = sel1.selector()->head()->unify_with(sel2.selector()->head(), ctx);
01048         pMergedWrapper->head(pMerged);
01049 
01050         DEBUG_EXEC(ALL, printCompoundSelector(pMerged, "MERGED: "))
01051 
01052         if (!pMerged) {
01053           return Node::createNil();
01054         }
01055 
01056         res.collection()->push_front(op1);
01057         res.collection()->push_front(Node::createSelector(pMergedWrapper, ctx));
01058 
01059         DEBUG_PRINTLN(ALL, "RESULT: " << res)
01060 
01061       } else {
01062         return Node::createNil();
01063       }
01064 
01065       return mergeFinalOps(seq1, seq2, ctx, res);
01066 
01067     } else if (!ops1.collection()->empty()) {
01068 
01069       Node op1 = ops1.collection()->front();
01070 
01071       if (op1.combinator() == Complex_Selector::PARENT_OF && !seq2.collection()->empty() && seq2.collection()->back().selector()->is_superselector_of(seq1.collection()->back().selector())) {
01072         seq2.collection()->pop_back();
01073       }
01074 
01075       // TODO: consider unshift(NodeCollection, Node)
01076       res.collection()->push_front(op1);
01077       res.collection()->push_front(seq1.collection()->back());
01078       seq1.collection()->pop_back();
01079 
01080       return mergeFinalOps(seq1, seq2, ctx, res);
01081 
01082     } else { // !ops2.collection()->empty()
01083 
01084       Node op2 = ops2.collection()->front();
01085 
01086       if (op2.combinator() == Complex_Selector::PARENT_OF && !seq1.collection()->empty() && seq1.collection()->back().selector()->is_superselector_of(seq2.collection()->back().selector())) {
01087         seq1.collection()->pop_back();
01088       }
01089 
01090       res.collection()->push_front(op2);
01091       res.collection()->push_front(seq2.collection()->back());
01092       seq2.collection()->pop_back();
01093 
01094       return mergeFinalOps(seq1, seq2, ctx, res);
01095 
01096     }
01097 
01098   }
01099 
01100 
01101   /*
01102     This is the equivalent of ruby's Sequence.subweave.
01103 
01104     Here is the original subweave code for reference during porting.
01105 
01106       def subweave(seq1, seq2)
01107         return [seq2] if seq1.empty?
01108         return [seq1] if seq2.empty?
01109 
01110         seq1, seq2 = seq1.dup, seq2.dup
01111         return unless init = merge_initial_ops(seq1, seq2)
01112         return unless fin = merge_final_ops(seq1, seq2)
01113         seq1 = group_selectors(seq1)
01114         seq2 = group_selectors(seq2)
01115         lcs = Sass::Util.lcs(seq2, seq1) do |s1, s2|
01116           next s1 if s1 == s2
01117           next unless s1.first.is_a?(SimpleSequence) && s2.first.is_a?(SimpleSequence)
01118           next s2 if parent_superselector?(s1, s2)
01119           next s1 if parent_superselector?(s2, s1)
01120         end
01121 
01122         diff = [[init]]
01123         until lcs.empty?
01124           diff << chunks(seq1, seq2) {|s| parent_superselector?(s.first, lcs.first)} << [lcs.shift]
01125           seq1.shift
01126           seq2.shift
01127         end
01128         diff << chunks(seq1, seq2) {|s| s.empty?}
01129         diff += fin.map {|sel| sel.is_a?(Array) ? sel : [sel]}
01130         diff.reject! {|c| c.empty?}
01131 
01132         result = Sass::Util.paths(diff).map {|p| p.flatten}.reject {|p| path_has_two_subjects?(p)}
01133 
01134         result
01135       end
01136   */
01137   static Node subweave(Node& one, Node& two, Context& ctx) {
01138     // Check for the simple cases
01139     if (one.collection()->size() == 0) {
01140       Node out = Node::createCollection();
01141       out.collection()->push_back(two);
01142       return out;
01143     }
01144     if (two.collection()->size() == 0) {
01145       Node out = Node::createCollection();
01146       out.collection()->push_back(one);
01147       return out;
01148     }
01149 
01150 
01151 
01152     Node seq1 = Node::createCollection();
01153     seq1.plus(one);
01154     Node seq2 = Node::createCollection();
01155     seq2.plus(two);
01156 
01157     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "SUBWEAVE ONE: " << seq1)
01158     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "SUBWEAVE TWO: " << seq2)
01159 
01160     Node init = mergeInitialOps(seq1, seq2, ctx);
01161     if (init.isNil()) {
01162       return Node::createNil();
01163     }
01164 
01165     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "INIT: " << init)
01166 
01167     Node res = Node::createCollection();
01168     Node fin = mergeFinalOps(seq1, seq2, ctx, res);
01169     if (fin.isNil()) {
01170       return Node::createNil();
01171     }
01172 
01173     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "FIN: " << fin)
01174 
01175 
01176     // Moving this line up since fin isn't modified between now and when it happened before
01177     // fin.map {|sel| sel.is_a?(Array) ? sel : [sel]}
01178 
01179     for (NodeDeque::iterator finIter = fin.collection()->begin(), finEndIter = fin.collection()->end();
01180            finIter != finEndIter; ++finIter) {
01181 
01182       Node& childNode = *finIter;
01183 
01184       if (!childNode.isCollection()) {
01185         Node wrapper = Node::createCollection();
01186         wrapper.collection()->push_back(childNode);
01187         childNode = wrapper;
01188       }
01189 
01190     }
01191 
01192     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "FIN MAPPED: " << fin)
01193 
01194 
01195 
01196     Node groupSeq1 = groupSelectors(seq1, ctx);
01197     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "SEQ1: " << groupSeq1)
01198 
01199     Node groupSeq2 = groupSelectors(seq2, ctx);
01200     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "SEQ2: " << groupSeq2)
01201 
01202 
01203     ComplexSelectorDeque groupSeq1Converted;
01204     nodeToComplexSelectorDeque(groupSeq1, groupSeq1Converted, ctx);
01205 
01206     ComplexSelectorDeque groupSeq2Converted;
01207     nodeToComplexSelectorDeque(groupSeq2, groupSeq2Converted, ctx);
01208 
01209     ComplexSelectorDeque out;
01210     LcsCollectionComparator collectionComparator(ctx);
01211     lcs(groupSeq2Converted, groupSeq1Converted, collectionComparator, ctx, out);
01212     Node seqLcs = complexSelectorDequeToNode(out, ctx);
01213 
01214     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "SEQLCS: " << seqLcs)
01215 
01216 
01217     Node initWrapper = Node::createCollection();
01218     initWrapper.collection()->push_back(init);
01219     Node diff = Node::createCollection();
01220     diff.collection()->push_back(initWrapper);
01221 
01222     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "DIFF INIT: " << diff)
01223 
01224 
01225     while (!seqLcs.collection()->empty()) {
01226       ParentSuperselectorChunker superselectorChunker(seqLcs, ctx);
01227       Node chunksResult = chunks(groupSeq1, groupSeq2, superselectorChunker);
01228       diff.collection()->push_back(chunksResult);
01229 
01230       Node lcsWrapper = Node::createCollection();
01231       lcsWrapper.collection()->push_back(seqLcs.collection()->front());
01232       seqLcs.collection()->pop_front();
01233       diff.collection()->push_back(lcsWrapper);
01234 
01235       groupSeq1.collection()->pop_front();
01236       groupSeq2.collection()->pop_front();
01237     }
01238 
01239     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "DIFF POST LCS: " << diff)
01240 
01241 
01242     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "CHUNKS: ONE=" << groupSeq1 << " TWO=" << groupSeq2)
01243 
01244 
01245     SubweaveEmptyChunker emptyChunker;
01246     Node chunksResult = chunks(groupSeq1, groupSeq2, emptyChunker);
01247     diff.collection()->push_back(chunksResult);
01248 
01249 
01250     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "DIFF POST CHUNKS: " << diff)
01251 
01252 
01253     diff.collection()->insert(diff.collection()->end(), fin.collection()->begin(), fin.collection()->end());
01254 
01255     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "DIFF POST FIN MAPPED: " << diff)
01256 
01257     // JMA - filter out the empty nodes (use a new collection, since iterator erase() invalidates the old collection)
01258     Node diffFiltered = Node::createCollection();
01259     for (NodeDeque::iterator diffIter = diff.collection()->begin(), diffEndIter = diff.collection()->end();
01260            diffIter != diffEndIter; ++diffIter) {
01261       Node& node = *diffIter;
01262       if (node.collection() && !node.collection()->empty()) {
01263         diffFiltered.collection()->push_back(node);
01264       }
01265     }
01266     diff = diffFiltered;
01267 
01268     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "DIFF POST REJECT: " << diff)
01269 
01270 
01271     Node pathsResult = paths(diff, ctx);
01272 
01273     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "PATHS: " << pathsResult)
01274 
01275 
01276     // We're flattening in place
01277     for (NodeDeque::iterator pathsIter = pathsResult.collection()->begin(), pathsEndIter = pathsResult.collection()->end();
01278       pathsIter != pathsEndIter; ++pathsIter) {
01279 
01280       Node& child = *pathsIter;
01281       child = flatten(child, ctx);
01282     }
01283 
01284     DEBUG_PRINTLN(SUBWEAVE, "FLATTENED: " << pathsResult)
01285 
01286 
01287     /*
01288       TODO: implement
01289       rejected = mapped.reject {|p| path_has_two_subjects?(p)}
01290       $stderr.puts "REJECTED: #{rejected}"
01291      */
01292 
01293 
01294     return pathsResult;
01295 
01296   }
01297   /*
01298   // disabled to avoid clang warning [-Wunused-function]
01299   static Node subweaveNaive(const Node& one, const Node& two, Context& ctx) {
01300     Node out = Node::createCollection();
01301 
01302     // Check for the simple cases
01303     if (one.isNil()) {
01304       out.collection()->push_back(two.clone(ctx));
01305     } else if (two.isNil()) {
01306       out.collection()->push_back(one.clone(ctx));
01307     } else {
01308       // Do the naive implementation. pOne = A B and pTwo = C D ...yields...  A B C D and C D A B
01309       // See https://gist.github.com/nex3/7609394 for details.
01310 
01311       Node firstPerm = one.clone(ctx);
01312       Node twoCloned = two.clone(ctx);
01313       firstPerm.plus(twoCloned);
01314       out.collection()->push_back(firstPerm);
01315 
01316       Node secondPerm = two.clone(ctx);
01317       Node oneCloned = one.clone(ctx);
01318       secondPerm.plus(oneCloned );
01319       out.collection()->push_back(secondPerm);
01320     }
01321 
01322     return out;
01323   }
01324   */
01325 
01326 
01327   /*
01328    This is the equivalent of ruby's Sequence.weave.
01329 
01330    The following is the modified version of the ruby code that was more portable to C++. You
01331    should be able to drop it into ruby 3.2.19 and get the same results from ruby sass.
01332 
01333       def weave(path)
01334         # This function works by moving through the selector path left-to-right,
01335         # building all possible prefixes simultaneously. These prefixes are
01336         # `befores`, while the remaining parenthesized suffixes is `afters`.
01337         befores = [[]]
01338         afters = path.dup
01339 
01340         until afters.empty?
01341           current = afters.shift.dup
01342           last_current = [current.pop]
01343 
01344           tempResult = []
01345 
01346           for before in befores do
01347             sub = subweave(before, current)
01348             if sub.nil?
01349               next
01350             end
01351 
01352             for seqs in sub do
01353               tempResult.push(seqs + last_current)
01354             end
01355           end
01356 
01357           befores = tempResult
01358 
01359         end
01360 
01361         return befores
01362       end
01363    */
01364   /*
01365       def weave(path)
01366         befores = [[]]
01367         afters = path.dup
01368 
01369         until afters.empty?
01370           current = afters.shift.dup
01371 
01372           last_current = [current.pop]
01373 
01374 
01375           tempResult = []
01376 
01377           for before in befores do
01378             sub = subweave(before, current)
01379 
01380             if sub.nil?
01381               next []
01382             end
01383 
01384 
01385             for seqs in sub do
01386               toPush = seqs + last_current
01387 
01388               tempResult.push(seqs + last_current)
01389             end
01390 
01391           end
01392 
01393           befores = tempResult
01394 
01395         end
01396 
01397         return befores
01398       end
01399   */
01400   static Node weave(Node& path, Context& ctx) {
01401 
01402     DEBUG_PRINTLN(WEAVE, "WEAVE: " << path)
01403 
01404     Node befores = Node::createCollection();
01405     befores.collection()->push_back(Node::createCollection());
01406 
01407     Node afters = Node::createCollection();
01408     afters.plus(path);
01409 
01410     while (!afters.collection()->empty()) {
01411       Node current = afters.collection()->front().clone(ctx);
01412       afters.collection()->pop_front();
01413       DEBUG_PRINTLN(WEAVE, "CURRENT: " << current)
01414 
01415       Node last_current = Node::createCollection();
01416       last_current.collection()->push_back(current.collection()->back());
01417       current.collection()->pop_back();
01418       DEBUG_PRINTLN(WEAVE, "CURRENT POST POP: " << current)
01419       DEBUG_PRINTLN(WEAVE, "LAST CURRENT: " << last_current)
01420 
01421       Node tempResult = Node::createCollection();
01422 
01423       for (NodeDeque::iterator beforesIter = befores.collection()->begin(), beforesEndIter = befores.collection()->end(); beforesIter != beforesEndIter; beforesIter++) {
01424         Node& before = *beforesIter;
01425 
01426         Node sub = subweave(before, current, ctx);
01427 
01428         DEBUG_PRINTLN(WEAVE, "SUB: " << sub)
01429 
01430         if (sub.isNil()) {
01431           return Node::createCollection();
01432         }
01433 
01434         for (NodeDeque::iterator subIter = sub.collection()->begin(), subEndIter = sub.collection()->end(); subIter != subEndIter; subIter++) {
01435           Node& seqs = *subIter;
01436 
01437           Node toPush = Node::createCollection();
01438           toPush.plus(seqs);
01439           toPush.plus(last_current);
01440 
01441           tempResult.collection()->push_back(toPush);
01442 
01443         }
01444       }
01445 
01446       befores = tempResult;
01447 
01448     }
01449 
01450     return befores;
01451   }
01452
